ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed Mandarin speaking and reading skills.
This course is a continuation of the Chinese language track. You continue to learn new vocabulary, grammar structures, and speaking techniques.
A greater mastery of formal Chinese, as well as the distinction between similar words and expanded vocabulary and speaking practice.
I learned a lot more about Chinese history and culture

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths across the board. Instructor's coursework material was helpful in explaining difficult points and for effectively learning new structures.
Tutoring sessions should be a little bit longer and more structured.
Strengths: wide variety of topics, fantastic professor Weaknesses: larger class sizes than other Chinese courses, which limits available speaking opportunities.
Strength is the reinforcement of the language through the quizlets, and the weakness is the workload

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I audited the course, but I would recommend taking it regardless. Again, the instructor's pedagogy was remarkably effective, and, even as an auditor, I know my language skills improved.

Yes! Zhou Laoshi is fantastic. Such a kind and competent teacher who is willing to accommodate your needs. This class is also only 3 days per week; while the average nightly homework is about equal to the earlier courses in Chinese, only having class 3 times per week really alleviates pressure and makes the class seem much more manageable.
Yes, this is a great class for getting better at Chinese.
Yeah, if you want to maintain your Chinese level and do more context work than language drills
